docs.lead_paragraph: Readers respond to a Sunday Review essay.

docs.lead_paragraph: Same-sex couples face difficulties in establishing legal ties not just to each other, but also to their children.

headline.seo: Same-Sex Couples Often Face Obstacles in Establishing Legal Ties to Children
headline.main: A Family With Two Moms, Except in the Eyes of the Law
headline.print_headline: A Family With Two Moms, Except in the Eyes of the Law

docs.abstract: Tara Siegel Bernard Your Money column observes that same-sex couples face difficulties establishing legal ties to each other and to their children, especially in states that do not allow both members of such couples to adopt; notes that other financial and legal problems abound, including difficulties with federal aid and inheritance.
docs.snippet: Same-sex couples face difficulties in establishing legal ties not just to each other, but also to their children.

headline.main: Interesting Deals That Flew Under the Radar

docs.abstract: The last several weeks have brought several fascinating, less noticed deals, including the Georgia Gulf/PPG deal and the holdings of Philip Falcone's special purpose entity.

docs.lead_paragraph: In his first year as Health and Human Services’ inspector general, Douglas Wilson has gotten impressive results in aggressively investigating Medicaid fraud cases. Another result is angry doctors.

docs.lead_paragraph: With 29 electoral votes at stake, President Obama attacked Mitt Romney on plans to repeal health care and transform Medicare.

headline.seo: Obama Seeks to Win Over Older Voters in Florida
headline.main: Obama Visits Florida to Win Over Older Voters
headline.print_headline: Obama Visits Florida to Win Over Older Voters

docs.abstract: Pres Obama opens a two-day campaign swing through Florida, attempting to build support in the battleground state by portraying Mitt Romney as a bad choice for older Americans.
docs.snippet: With 29 electoral votes at stake, President Obama attacked Mitt Romney on plans to repeal health care and transform Medicare.

docs.lead_paragraph: Walgreen agreed to renew its relationship with the prescription benefit manager Express Scripts, opening the door for customers to return in September for discounts and related benefits from their Express Scripts drug cards.

headline.main: Walgreen and Express Scripts Reach Deal
headline.print_headline: Walgreen and Express Scripts Reach Deal

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Paul R. LePage is planning to cut thousands of people from Maine’s Medicaid rolls, arguing that the recent Supreme Court ruling on the law gives him license to do so.

headline.seo: Debate in Maine Hints at Medicaid Conflict After Health Care Ruling
headline.main: Maine Debate Hints at Rift on Medicaid After Ruling
headline.print_headline: Maine Debate Hints at Rift On Medicaid After Ruling

docs.abstract: Gov Paul R LePage of Maine, citing the Supreme Court' s ruling on the Affordable Care Act, is planning to cut thousands of people from Maine's Medicaid rolls; move could lead to a direct confrontation with the Obama administration, and may presage political and legal conflicts between the federal government and other states as they grapple with implications of the Supreme Court decision.
docs.snippet: Gov. Paul R. LePage is planning to cut thousands of people from Maine’s Medicaid rolls, arguing that the recent Supreme Court ruling on the law gives him license to do so.

keywords.name: subject

byline.contributor: Abby Goodnough reported from Augusta, and Robert Pear from Washington.
byline.original: By ABBY GOODNOUGH and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Nebraska rightly dismissed a lawsuit against the requirement in the new health care law that most employers provide insurance coverage for contraception.
docs.abstract: Editorial welcomes decision by Federal Judge Warren Urbom to dismiss lawsuit filed by seven state attorneys general against the requirement in the new health care law that most employers provide insurance coverage for contraception; criticizes mandate's opponents for heedlessly rushing to the courts despite the administration's generous promise to accommodate the demands of religious employers.
docs.snippet: A federal judge in Nebraska rightly dismissed a lawsuit against the requirement in the new health care law that most employers provide insurance coverage for contraception.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Retirees who were offered pension buyouts from General Motors are finding the decision, a lump-sum check or continued monthly payments, anything but simple.

headline.seo: Retirees Wrestle With Pension Buyout From General Motors
headline.main: Retirees Wrestle With Pension Buyout From General Motors

docs.abstract: About 42,000 General Motors retirees and their surviving spouses who have been offered pension buyouts from the company are grappling with the decision between receiving a lump-sum payout or continued monthly payments; choice prompts deep, often uncomfortable, consideration of both one's personal finances and one's mortality.
docs.snippet: Retirees who were offered pension buyouts from General Motors are finding the decision, a lump-sum check or continued monthly payments, anything but simple.
